title: Psalms Chapter 88 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 88 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 88 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 88.

questions.question: Who is the author of Psalms 88 according to the chapter heading?
questions.correctAnswer: Heman the Ezrahite
questions.explanation: Psalms 88:1 states it is a Maschil of Heman the Ezrahite.

questions.question: What is the psalmist’s request in Psalms 88:2?
options: Let my prayer come before thee
questions.correctAnswer: Let my prayer come before thee
questions.explanation: Psalms 88:2 says, 'Let my prayer come before thee: incline thine ear unto my cry;'

questions.question: According to Psalms 88:3, what is the state of the psalmist's soul?
questions.correctAnswer: Full of troubles
questions.explanation: Verse 3 states, 'For my soul is full of troubles'.

questions.question: In Psalms 88:4, with whom does the psalmist say he is counted?
options: Them that go down into the pit
questions.correctAnswer: Them that go down into the pit
questions.explanation: Verse 4 says, 'I am counted with them that go down into the pit'.

questions.question: What does Psalms 88:5 say about the dead?
options: They are cut off from God's hand
questions.correctAnswer: They are cut off from God's hand
questions.explanation: Verse 5 states, 'whom thou rememberest no more: and they are cut off from thy hand.'

questions.question: Where has God laid the psalmist according to Psalms 88:6?
questions.correctAnswer: In the lowest pit
questions.explanation: Verse 6 says, 'Thou hast laid me in the lowest pit, in darkness, in the deeps.'

questions.question: What has the LORD’s wrath done to the psalmist as per Psalms 88:7?
questions.correctAnswer: It lieth hard upon him
questions.explanation: Verse 7 says, 'Thy wrath lieth hard upon me'.

questions.question: According to Psalms 88:8, what has God made the psalmist to his acquaintances?
questions.correctAnswer: An abomination
questions.explanation: Verse 8 states, 'thou hast made me an abomination unto them'.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 88:10 asks if the dead shall arise and praise God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 10 asks, 'shall the dead arise and praise thee?'

questions.question: According to Psalms 88:13, when does the psalmist say he will cry unto the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: In the morning
questions.explanation: Verse 13 states, 'in the morning shall my prayer prevent thee.'

questions.question: What question does the psalmist ask the LORD in Psalms 88:14?
options: Why castest thou off my soul?
questions.correctAnswer: Why castest thou off my soul?
questions.explanation: Verse 14 says, 'LORD, why castest thou off my soul?'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 88:15 states the psalmist has been afflicted and ready to die from his youth up.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 15 states, 'I am afflicted and ready to die from my youth up.'

questions.question: What surrounds the psalmist daily according to Psalms 88:17?
questions.correctAnswer: Terrors like water
questions.explanation: Verse 17 says, 'They came round about me daily like water; they compassed me about together.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 88:9: 'Mine eye mourneth by reason of ________.'
questions.correctAnswer: affliction
questions.explanation: Psalms 88:9 says, 'Mine eye mourneth by reason of affliction.'

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 88:18, the LORD has put lover and friend far from the psalmist.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 18 states, 'Lover and friend hast thou put far from me.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 88 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 88 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 88, what biblical truth would you share about perseverance in prayer?
options: Prayer should be continual, both day and night.
God does not hear prayers made in distress.
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer should be continual, both day and night.
questions.explanation: Psalms 88:1 and 88:9 show the psalmist crying out day and night and calling daily upon the Lord, teaching us to persevere in prayer even in times of trouble.

questions.question: How does Psalms 88 teach us to approach God when feeling abandoned and afflicted?
options: Continue to cry out to the Lord despite feelings of abandonment.
Stop praying because God has hidden His face.
Ignore God and rely on personal strength.
questions.correctAnswer: Continue to cry out to the Lord despite feelings of abandonment.
questions.explanation: Verses 13 and 14 show the psalmist crying to the Lord in the morning and questioning why God hides His face, yet still continuing to pray, demonstrating faithful persistence.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by troubles and compares their life to drawing near the grave. What biblical reality does Psalms 88 reveal about such experiences?
options: The believer may feel surrounded by darkness and affliction but is encouraged to continue seeking God.
Troubles mean God has abandoned the believer completely.
Suffering is a sign of sin without hope of restoration.
Troubles should be ignored to remain faithful.
questions.correctAnswer: The believer may feel surrounded by darkness and affliction but is encouraged to continue seeking God.
questions.explanation: Verses 3, 6, and 7 describe the soul full of troubles and being laid in deep darkness, yet the psalmist still prays and seeks God, teaching that trials are part of faith but do not end God's care.

questions.question: How does Psalms 88 illustrate the importance of honesty in prayer during spiritual despair?
options: It shows that believers can openly express feelings of abandonment and despair to God.
It teaches that only joyful prayers are acceptable.
Believers should hide their doubts from God.
Prayer must be formal and never express personal feelings.
questions.correctAnswer: It shows that believers can openly express feelings of abandonment and despair to God.
questions.explanation: Verses 14 and 15 highlight the psalmist asking why God has cast off his soul and describing affliction from youth, modeling honest communication with God in prayer.

questions.question: A believer struggles with feelings of isolation and rejection. What lesson about fellowship and God's presence can be drawn from Psalms 88?
options: God may allow separation from friends, but the believer should still seek Him earnestly.
Isolation means God has rejected the believer permanently.
Friends should be avoided to prevent disappointment.
questions.correctAnswer: God may allow separation from friends, but the believer should still seek Him earnestly.
questions.explanation: Verse 8 and 18 describe acquaintances and loved ones being put far away, yet the psalmist continues crying out to God, teaching that God's presence remains important even amid social isolation.

questions.question: According to Psalms 88, how should a believer respond to the feeling of being overwhelmed by God's wrath and affliction?
options: Continue seeking God in prayer despite the affliction and terrors.
Reject God because of His wrath.
questions.correctAnswer: Continue seeking God in prayer despite the affliction and terrors.
questions.explanation: Verses 7, 15, and 16 describe God's wrath and terrors afflicting the psalmist, yet he persists in prayer, showing the biblical virtue of perseverance in faith during trials.

questions.question: What does Psalms 88 teach us about expressing grief and despair in our relationship with God?
options: It is acceptable and honest to express deep sorrow and confusion to God.
Grief should always be hidden from God.
Despair means God is displeased with the believer.
Only positive emotions should be shared in prayer.
questions.correctAnswer: It is acceptable and honest to express deep sorrow and confusion to God.
questions.explanation: The psalmist openly mourns and asks God why He has hidden His face (verses 9 and 14), showing that expressing sorrow is part of a genuine faith relationship.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 88 assures believers that God's lovingkindness and faithfulness are always declared openly, even in the grave and darkness.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 10 to 12 question whether wonders, lovingkindness, and faithfulness can be declared in the grave or darkness, expressing doubt, which shows the psalmist’s deep despair rather than assurance.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 88, the psalmist feels that God has forgotten him and cut him off from His hand.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 5 explicitly states that the psalmist feels like those whom God remembers no more and who are cut off from His hand, reflecting a sense of abandonment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The psalmist describes his soul as being full of ______ and his life drawing near unto the grave.
questions.correctAnswer: troubles
questions.explanation: Psalms 88:3 states, 'For my soul is full of troubles: and my life draweth nigh unto the grave,' showing the psalmist's deep distress.

questions.question: How does Psalms 88 encourage believers to maintain integrity during times of spiritual darkness and distress?
options: By continuing to call upon the Lord and stretching out hands in prayer.
By pretending to be joyful to others.
By avoiding prayer until feeling better.
By isolating oneself completely from others.
questions.correctAnswer: By continuing to call upon the Lord and stretching out hands in prayer.
questions.explanation: Verse 9 emphasizes daily calling upon the Lord and stretching out hands, teaching faithful dependence on God even when overwhelmed.

questions.question: What practical lesson about humility can we learn from the psalmist's acknowledgment of his weakness in Psalms 88?
options: Recognizing our weakness before God is a step toward trusting Him.
We should hide our weakness to appear strong.
Weakness means God is displeased with us.
questions.correctAnswer: Recognizing our weakness before God is a step toward trusting Him.
questions.explanation: Verse 4 describes the psalmist as a man with no strength, counted among those who go down into the pit, indicating honest humility before God in suffering.

questions.question: According to Psalms 88, how can a believer find hope when feeling surrounded by troubles like water?
options: By continuing to cry out to God despite feeling overwhelmed.
By giving up because troubles are too many.
By ignoring God and relying on self.
By blaming others for their troubles.
questions.correctAnswer: By continuing to cry out to God despite feeling overwhelmed.
questions.explanation: Verse 17 describes troubles coming around like water, yet the psalmist’s persistent prayer throughout the chapter encourages us to maintain faith and prayer.

questions.question: In Psalms 88, what does the psalmist imply about God’s knowledge of the dead?
options: God remembers the dead no more and they are cut off from His hand.
God always raises the dead to praise Him.
The dead declare God’s lovingkindness openly.
The dead are close to God’s presence.
questions.correctAnswer: God remembers the dead no more and they are cut off from His hand.
questions.explanation: Verse 5 clearly states that those lying in the grave are cut off from God’s hand and are not remembered by Him, expressing the psalmist’s sense of abandonment.

questions.question: What does Psalms 88 teach about faithfulness in the face of prolonged suffering from youth?
options: Faithfulness includes crying out to God even when afflicted from youth.
Suffering from youth means God has rejected you.
One should stop praying if suffering lasts long.
God does not care about long-term suffering.
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness includes crying out to God even when afflicted from youth.
questions.explanation: Verse 15 describes the psalmist as afflicted and ready to die from youth, yet he continues to seek God, showing perseverance in faith despite long suffering.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 88 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 88.

questions.question: What is the primary mood conveyed in Psalms 88, as expressed by the psalmist's cry before God?
questions.correctAnswer: Desperation and deep affliction
questions.explanation: The psalmist cries day and night to the LORD God of his salvation, indicating deep distress and affliction (Psalms 88:1-2).

questions.question: In Psalms 88:4, the psalmist compares himself to which figure or state?
options: A man that hath no strength
questions.correctAnswer: A man that hath no strength
questions.explanation: The psalmist states, 'I am as a man that hath no strength,' showing his weakness and despair (Psalms 88:4).

questions.question: What is the significance of the psalmist being 'laid in the lowest pit, in darkness, in the deeps' in Psalms 88:6?
options: It symbolizes profound abandonment and despair
It indicates a place of honor and rest
It refers to a physical prison
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes profound abandonment and despair
questions.explanation: The 'lowest pit' and 'darkness' metaphorically represent the psalmist's deep suffering and sense of being forsaken by God (Psalms 88:6).

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 88:10-12, the psalmist expresses doubt that God's wonders and lovingkindness are revealed in death or the grave.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The psalmist questions whether wonders and lovingkindness can be shown or declared among the dead or in the grave (Psalms 88:10-12).

questions.question: Which literary device is prominently used in Psalms 88:17, where terrors are described as coming 'like water' and compassing the psalmist about?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: The terrors are described using 'like water,' which is a simile comparing the overwhelming nature of affliction to water (Psalms 88:17).

questions.question: What is the role of 'Selah' as found in Psalms 88:7 and 88:10 within the psalm's structure?
options: It serves as a musical or meditative pause
It signals the end of the psalm
questions.correctAnswer: It serves as a musical or meditative pause
questions.explanation: 'Selah' is traditionally understood as a pause for contemplation or musical interlude, emphasizing the gravity of the preceding statement (Psalms 88:7, 10).

questions.question: How does Psalms 88 reflect the theme of divine abandonment found in other biblical texts such as Psalm 22 and Lamentations?
options: It echoes the feeling of being forsaken by God in extreme distress
It celebrates God's faithfulness in adversity
It focuses on communal worship and joy
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes the feeling of being forsaken by God in extreme distress
questions.explanation: Similar to Psalm 22 and Lamentations, Psalms 88 expresses the psalmist's deep sense of abandonment and despair (Psalms 88:14).

questions.question: In Psalms 88:5, the psalmist says, 'Free among the dead, like the slain that lie in the grave, whom thou rememberest no more.' What theological concept does this evoke?
options: The finality and silence of death
questions.correctAnswer: The finality and silence of death
questions.explanation: This verse emphasizes the psalmist’s feeling of exclusion from God's remembrance, highlighting death's finality and abandonment (Psalms 88:5).

questions.question: What is the significance of the psalmist's repeated phrase about crying to the LORD both day and night (Psalms 88:1 and 88:13) in terms of Hebrew poetic parallelism?
options: It emphasizes persistent and continual prayer
It signals a change from lament to praise
It is a metaphor for physical exhaustion
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes persistent and continual prayer
questions.explanation: The repetition in Hebrew poetry often stresses the intensity and constancy of the psalmist’s cries to God (Psalms 88:1, 13).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Psalms 88:8, the psalmist says, 'Thou hast put away mine acquaintance far from me; thou hast made me an ________ unto them.'
questions.correctAnswer: abomination
questions.explanation: The psalmist laments being made an 'abomination' in the eyes of his acquaintances, highlighting social rejection (Psalms 88:8).

questions.question: How does the psalmist's reference to 'thy fierce wrath' and 'thy terrors' in Psalms 88:16 reflect ancient Near Eastern understandings of divine judgment?
options: It reflects the belief that God's wrath is overwhelming and destructive
It suggests gods were indifferent to humans
It denies the existence of divine wrath
It portrays wrath as a minor irritation
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the belief that God's wrath is overwhelming and destructive
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, divine wrath was often seen as powerful and terrifying, as depicted in the psalmist's description (Psalms 88:16).

questions.question: Which ancient Israelite group is associated with the authorship or performance of Psalms 88, as indicated in verse 1?
questions.correctAnswer: The sons of Korah
questions.explanation: The title states this psalm is for the sons of Korah, a Levitical family known for temple music (Psalms 88:1).

questions.question: In Psalms 88:9, the psalmist mentions stretching out his hands to the LORD. What is the cultural significance of this gesture in ancient Israelite prayer?
options: It is a gesture of victory
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes pleading and supplication
questions.explanation: Stretching out hands was a common posture expressing earnest pleading and dependence on God (Psalms 88:9).

questions.question: What is the implication of the psalmist's question in Psalms 88:14, 'Why castest thou off my soul? why hidest thou thy face from me?' in the wider biblical context of God's presence?
options: It reflects the anguish of perceived divine abandonment
It expresses certainty of God's constant presence
It is a rhetorical question affirming joy
It refers to God's hidden plan to bless
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the anguish of perceived divine abandonment
questions.explanation: The psalmist's question reveals a deep sense of separation from God, a theme found in many laments (Psalms 88:14).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Psalms 88:15, the psalmist states, 'I am afflicted and ready to die from my ______ up.'
questions.correctAnswer: youth
questions.explanation: The psalmist laments suffering from youth, showing long-term affliction (Psalms 88:15).

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 88 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 88 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary emotional state expressed by the psalmist in Psalms 88?
questions.correctAnswer: Despair and affliction
questions.explanation: The psalmist repeatedly expresses deep distress, affliction, and a sense of being overwhelmed by troubles (Psalms 88:3, 88:7, 88:15). This emotional state is consistent with biblical depictions of lament and human suffering (e.g., Job 3:11-26, Lamentations 3:1-20, Romans 8:18, 2 Corinthians 1:8-9).

questions.question: In Psalms 88, how does the psalmist describe his relationship to the dead?
options: As counted among the dead and cut off from God's hand
As victorious over death through faith
As a mediator between the living and the dead
As someone who will be resurrected immediately
questions.correctAnswer: As counted among the dead and cut off from God's hand
questions.explanation: The psalmist identifies himself as one who is 'counted with them that go down into the pit' and is 'cut off from thy hand' (Psalms 88:4-5). This reflects a profound sense of separation and despair, consistent with Old Testament views of death and separation from God (Ecclesiastes 9:5, Psalms 6:5, Isaiah 38:18, Hebrews 9:27).

questions.question: What theological question does the psalmist ask about God's wonders and faithfulness in the grave?
options: Will the dead praise God or declare His faithfulness?
Will God forgive sins in the afterlife?
Will God punish the wicked after death?
questions.correctAnswer: Will the dead praise God or declare His faithfulness?
questions.explanation: The psalmist questions if God's wonders and lovingkindness are shown to the dead and if the dead can praise Him (Psalms 88:10-11). This raises theological reflections on God's power over death and the hope of resurrection, themes developed in Isaiah 26:19, Daniel 12:2, John 11:25, and 1 Corinthians 15.

questions.question: According to Psalms 88, what effect has God's wrath had on the psalmist?
options: Afflicted him and overwhelmed him with waves
questions.correctAnswer: Afflicted him and overwhelmed him with waves
questions.explanation: The psalmist states that God's wrath lies hard upon him and that he is afflicted with all God's waves (Psalms 88:7). This imagery expresses divine judgment and suffering, paralleling other biblical passages like Jonah 2:3, Psalms 69:1-2, Nahum 1:2, and Romans 1:18.

questions.question: What does the psalmist say about his social relationships in Psalms 88?
options: He is abandoned and made an abomination to his acquaintances
He is surrounded by faithful friends
He leads a joyful community worship
questions.correctAnswer: He is abandoned and made an abomination to his acquaintances
questions.explanation: The psalmist laments that God has put away his acquaintances far from him and made him an abomination to them (Psalms 88:8), illustrating a sense of social isolation similar to Job's experience (Job 19:13-19), Jeremiah's rejection (Jeremiah 15:17), and Jesus' rejection (John 1:11).

questions.question: What is the significance of the repeated calls to prayer in Psalms 88?
options: They reveal persistent faith despite despair
They indicate a loss of faith
They show that God has answered already
questions.correctAnswer: They reveal persistent faith despite despair
questions.explanation: The psalmist calls daily upon God and cries out in prayer, showing persistence in seeking God even amid suffering (Psalms 88:1, 88:9, 88:13). This reflects biblical teaching on perseverance in prayer found in Luke 18:1-8, 1 Thessalonians 5:17, Romans 12:12, and James 5:16.

questions.question: Which phrase best describes the psalmist’s experience of God's presence in Psalms 88?
options: God hides His face and casts off the soul
questions.correctAnswer: God hides His face and casts off the soul
questions.explanation: The psalmist explicitly asks why God has cast off his soul and hidden His face from him (Psalms 88:14), indicating a feeling of divine abandonment, a theme also found in Psalms 22:1, Isaiah 54:7, Lamentations 3:8, and Mark 15:34.

questions.question: How does Psalms 88 depict the psalmist’s physical and emotional condition?
options: Afflicted, ready to die, distracted by terrors
questions.correctAnswer: Afflicted, ready to die, distracted by terrors
questions.explanation: The psalmist describes himself as afflicted and ready to die from youth, suffering terrors that distract him (Psalms 88:15). This mirrors the biblical reality of human frailty and suffering (Psalm 31:10, Isaiah 38:1, 2 Corinthians 4:8-9, Hebrews 4:15).

questions.question: What metaphor is used in Psalms 88 to describe the psalmist’s troubles surrounding him?
options: Troubles surround him daily like water
questions.correctAnswer: Troubles surround him daily like water
questions.explanation: The psalmist says troubles come around him daily like water, encompassing him (Psalms 88:17). This metaphor is similar to imagery in Psalms 42:7, Isaiah 43:2, Jonah 2:3, and Matthew 8:26 about overwhelming adversity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 88, what has happened to the psalmist’s lover and friend?
options: They have been put far from him and into darkness
They have remained faithful and close
They have been comforted by God
questions.correctAnswer: They have been put far from him and into darkness
questions.explanation: The psalmist laments that lover and friend have been put far from him and his acquaintances into darkness (Psalms 88:18), highlighting profound isolation similar to the experiences of Jeremiah (Jeremiah 20:10) and Jesus (John 15:18-20).

questions.question: What does the psalmist request God to do with his prayer in Psalms 88?
options: Let his prayer come before God and incline His ear
Send an angel to comfort him
questions.correctAnswer: Let his prayer come before God and incline His ear
questions.explanation: The psalmist asks God to let his prayer come before Him and to incline His ear to his cry (Psalms 88:2), indicating a desire for God’s attentive presence, consistent with biblical teaching on God's responsiveness to prayer (1 Kings 8:28, Psalms 34:15, Isaiah 59:1, 1 John 5:14).

questions.question: How does Psalms 88 describe the place where God has laid the psalmist?
options: In the lowest pit, in darkness, in the deeps
On a high mountain with light
questions.correctAnswer: In the lowest pit, in darkness, in the deeps
questions.explanation: The psalmist says God has laid him in the lowest pit, in darkness, in the deeps (Psalms 88:6), symbolizing deep despair and separation from God's presence, paralleling themes in Jonah 2:6, Psalms 130:1, Isaiah 38:10, and 2 Corinthians 12:7-9.

questions.question: What key attribute of God is highlighted by the psalmist’s struggle in Psalms 88?
questions.correctAnswer: God’s justice and wrath
questions.explanation: The psalmist acknowledges God's fierce wrath and terrors upon him (Psalms 88:16), reflecting God's holiness and justice against sin (Nahum 1:2-3, Romans 1:18, Hebrews 10:31, Revelation 6:16-17).

questions.question: Which of the following best captures the theological tension in Psalms 88?
options: Faithful crying out amid perceived divine abandonment
Confident assurance of salvation without struggle
Celebration of God's blessings and victory
A call for vengeance against enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Faithful crying out amid perceived divine abandonment
questions.explanation: The psalmist persistently cries to God despite feeling abandoned and hidden from God’s presence (Psalms 88:1, 88:14), illustrating the tension between faith and suffering seen in biblical figures like Job (Job 13:15), David (Psalms 22), and Paul (2 Corinthians 12:8-9).

questions.question: What messianic or Christological theme can be discerned in Psalms 88?
options: The experience of abandonment and suffering before deliverance
The immediate resurrection from the grave
The establishment of a political kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: The experience of abandonment and suffering before deliverance
questions.explanation: The psalm’s theme of abandonment echoes Christ’s cry on the cross (Mark 15:34) and prefigures the Messiah’s sufferings (Isaiah 53:3-4, Psalms 22), pointing to the path of redemptive suffering and eventual deliverance.
